head.title: Ultra-Lightweight, Flexible InGaP/GaAs Tandem Solar Cells with a Dual-Function Encapsulation Layer | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Ultra-Lightweight, Flexible InGaP/GaAs Tandem Solar Cells with a Dual-Function Encapsulation Layer

Lightweight, flexible solar cells from III–V semiconductors offer new application opportunities for devices that require a power supply, such as cars, drones, satellites, or wearable devices, due to their outstanding efficiency and power-to-weight ratio (specific power). However, the specific power and stability of flexible photovoltaic (PV) devices need to be enhanced for use in such applications because current flexible PV devices are vulnerable to moisture and heat. Here, we develop ultra-lightweight, flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer that serves as both a moisture barrier and an antireflection coating for the active device layer. Using a thin polymer film as a substrate and an ultrathin metal as a bonding layer, the total weight of the device is dramatically reduced. Therefore, the specific power of our solar cells is remarkably high with a value of over 5000 W/kg under the AM 1.5G solar spectrum. Additionally, there is no degradation even if the solar cells are exposed to harsh environmental conditions.

div.span: SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

img.alt: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

div.p: Lightweight, flexible solar cells from III–V semiconductors offer new application opportunities for devices that require a power supply, such as cars, drones, satellites, or wearable devices, due to their outstanding efficiency and power-to-weight ratio (specific power). However, the specific power and stability of flexible photovoltaic (PV) devices need to be enhanced for use in such applications because current flexible PV devices are vulnerable to moisture and heat. Here, we develop ultra-lightweight, flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer that serves as both a moisture barrier and an antireflection coating for the active device layer. Using a thin polymer film as a substrate and an ultrathin metal as a bonding layer, the total weight of the device is dramatically reduced. Therefore, the specific power of our solar cells is remarkably high with a value of over 5000 W/kg under the AM 1.5G solar spectrum. Additionally, there is no degradation even if the solar cells are exposed to harsh environmental conditions.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Flexible solar cells are in the spotlight due to their possibilities to be utilized as mobile equipment, such as cars, drones, space satellites,
(1−3)
or wearable devices.
(4−6)
Perovskite, organic materials, and amorphous silicon are mainly researched for obtaining flexible and lightweight solar cells, largely due to their reasonable light absorption properties, a fabrication temperature that is compatible with flexible substrates, and their reasonable manufacturing cost.
(7−10)
However, these materials are not ideal for highly efficient and reliable devices due to the degradation of their performance over time and the poor minority carrier lifetime caused by their disordered and defective structures.
(11−13)
These disadvantages are problematic in powering mobile equipment or portable devices. This is because to supply power to mobile equipment or portable devices, high power is required in a limited area without deteriorating performance. To solve this problem, III–V semiconducting materials that exhibit excellent optical and electrical properties allow the fabrication of extremely efficient photovoltaic (PV) devices with a thin geometry.
(14−18)

The power-to-weight ratio (specific power) is a critical parameter for flexible or lightweight solar cells.
(19)
The specific power of solar cells must be reasonably high to be used in mobile equipment, such as cars, drones, space satellites, or wearable devices. Previously, flexible III–V solar cells were fabricated on a Cu substrate
(20,21)
or metal foil.
(22−24)
However, metals including Cu are heavy and not very flexible; therefore, as alternative materials to metals, polymer films have recently been widely used as substrates to reduce weight and enhance flexibility. Even with a polymer film as a substrate, not sufficiently thin polymer films and a few microns thick bonding materials are used in the fabrication of flexible solar cells, thus still exhibiting drawbacks in specific power.
(25−29)
Therefore, the weight and thickness of the substrate and bonding material must be reduced to enhance the specific power.

In addition, mobile devices are easily exposed to harsh environments such as ambient moisture and heat; thus, an encapsulation layer protecting them is indispensable. Typically, III–V solar cells are significantly degraded by exposure to ambient moisture.
(30,31)
Therefore, it is necessary to block moisture to improve the stability of III–V solar cells. As a result, various encapsulation layers based on Al
2
O
3
, SiN
x
, SiO
x
, or organic–inorganic hybrid materials have been reported.
(32−34)
Among them, Al
2
O
3
deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD) is known to act as a good barrier from moisture and heat.
(35,36)
Furthermore, an antireflection coating (ARC) layer that effectively minimizes the reflection of light at the surface of solar cells is an essential part of solar cells to fabricate high-efficiency solar cells. In order to have a clear ARC effect, the closer the material to the area where the light reaches, the lower the refractive index of that material. Also, double encapsulation layers have been reported to be efficient ARC layers, thus enhancing light absorption into solar cells.
(37)
Based on this perspective, double encapsulation layers based on Al
2
O
3
deposited by ALD can be good candidates that serve as both moisture barriers and ARC layers.

Here, we report flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer. In this study, a light polyimide film (Kapton, DuPont, ∼13 μm) was used as a substrate, a thin metal of Pt/Au (10/60 nm) was used as a bonding layer, and a thin encapsulation layer of Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
(50/44 nm) with an ARC effect was developed through refractive index design. Through the weight reduction of the substrate and the decreased thickness of the bonding material, we have achieved the highest specific power that has been reported for flexible III–V PV devices, along with high efficiency. These results show that the prepared solar cells show promising applicability for use in mobile equipment or wearable devices requiring high power and mechanical flexibility.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a–d shows the four main steps to fabricate flexible InGaP/GaAs solar cells. The process began with a metal wafer bonding technique,
(38)
which could enhance the specific power of the solar cells. Pt (10 nm) and Au (60 nm) were deposited onto an InGaP/GaAs solar cell wafer and a thin polymer film on a glass substrate, respectively, as a temporary, rigid support to facilitate manual manipulation. Uniquely, in the fabrication process, Pt/Au, which served as both the back Ohmic contact and the bonding layer, was deposited onto the back surface of the solar cell. After the polyimide film and a solar cell wafer were treated by argon (Ar) plasma for surface activation, they were bonded manually in air (
Figure
1
a). GaAs substrates were selectively etched to form the final structure. The fabrication process involved the formation of a defined front contact grid consisting of Pd (20 nm), Ge (40 nm), and Au (300 nm) using an e-beam evaporator. A mesa isolation process was carried out by a combination of inductively coupled plasma–reactive ion etching (ICP–RIE) and wet chemical etching (
Figure
1
b). Al
2
O
3
(50 nm) and SiO
2
(44 nm), as a dual-function encapsulation layer that served as both a moisture barrier and ARC layer, were deposited on the active device layer using ALD and a subsequent plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) when the solar cell fabrication was completed (
Figure
1
c). The device was then peeled away from the handling glass after the overall fabrication process was completed (
Figure
1
d).
Figure
1
e shows a schematic illustration of the material stack in an exploded view.
Figure
1
f shows an image of the prepared thin cells transferred onto a lightweight polyimide film that was bent around a curved surface with a radius of curvature of 1.5 cm, which exhibits the high flexibility of the device. The theoretical maximum strain of the fabricated solar cells (5.43 μm) with a bending radius of 1.5 cm is 0.036%.
(39)
In terms of flexibility, design of flexible solar cells can be optimized by using a thinner substrate and reducing the thickness of each layer of the solar cell through epi structure engineering.

div.p:
Figure 1. Schematic illustration of fabricating flexible solar cells with high specific power and stability: (a) bonding of Pt/Au on the solar cell wafer and Pt/Au on the polyimide film (Kapton, 13 μm) by the wafer bonding technique. (b) Photolithography, electron-beam evaporation, and etching for device isolation. (c) Deposition of Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
by ALD and PECVD. (d) Release of the final flexible solar cell from the glass substrate. (e) Schematic illustration of the material stack at the location of an InGaP/GaAs solar cell. (f) Photograph of flexible solar cells with Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
encapsulation.

div.div:
An inverted dual-junction InGaP/GaAs solar cell structure, which is schematically illustrated in
Figure
2
a, has been grown on 2° misoriented GaAs substrates.
(40)
In this structure, the GaAs wafer serves only as an epitaxial matrix and is not part of the solar cell. Additionally, the growth of a GaAs buffer layer, which is also not part of the solar cell, is essential to prevent degradation of the open-circuit voltage (
V
oc
) caused by misfit dislocations.
(41)
The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) cross-sectional image in
Figure
2
b reveals that the InGaP/GaAs solar cell wafer is bonded onto the polyimide film with good uniformity and without any voids at the bonding interface. To investigate the transferred epitaxial layer on the polyimide film, X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were obtained. For comparison, XRD measurements on the reference solar cell were also obtained. As shown in
Figure
2
c, Au(200), Pt(311), InGaP(400), and GaAs(400) peaks are observed for the solar cells on polyimide films, whereas the reference solar cell shows only InGaP(400) and GaAs(400) peaks. These diffraction patterns indicate that the epitaxial transfer and metal bonding have been successful.

div.p: Figure 2. (a) Schematic illustration of the inverted dual-junction InGaP/GaAs cell grown on GaAs substrates. (b) Bonding interface SEM image of the solar cell and polyimide film (left). Magnified view of a bonding interface (right). (c) 2θ XRD profiles of the reference solar cell and the solar cell on the polyimide film.

div.div:
Figure
3
a shows the current density–voltage (
J
–
V
) characteristics of our flexible solar cells with an area of 32.7 mm
2
using simulated AM 1.5G illumination at 1000 W/m
2
and room temperature. As seen, flexible InGaP/GaAs solar cells without an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer demonstrate a conversion efficiency of 21.1 ± 0.2%, a
V
oc
of 2.4 ± 0.03 V, a short-circuit current density (
J
sc
) of 10.2 ± 0.2 mA/cm
2
, and a fill factor (FF) of 87 ± 0.4%. However, flexible InGaP/GaAs solar cells with an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer demonstrate a conversion efficiency of 27.4 ± 0.3%, a
V
oc
of 2.4 ± 0.03 V, a
J
sc
of 13.1 ± 0.1 mA/cm
2
, and an FF of 88 ± 0.4%. Flexible InGaP/GaAs solar cells with an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer demonstrate better performance than those without an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer. Multiple devices (>6) of the same size were fabricated in the same wafer. When these devices were compared to those grown on conventional GaAs substrates uprightly, there was little difference in performance (<2%).
Figure
3
b shows the measured external quantum efficiency (EQE) of those solar cells with an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer.
Figure
3
c compares the reflectance for solar cells with and without the Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer that is evaluated using the finite difference time domain (FDTD) technique and experimental measurements. Since Al
2
O
3
(50 nm) deposited by ALD acts as a reasonable moisture barrier,
(36)
the SiO
2
thickness (44 nm) was optimized through FDTD simulation. As seen in the experimental measurements using a UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer, solar cells with an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer reflect less light than those without an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer. Similar results are shown in the FDTD simulation; as expected, the Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer has an essential ARC effect. The FDTD simulation assumes ideal surface profiles as the diffractive top surfaces of the solar cells. These structures diffract the incident solar spectrum inside the solar cells. In the case of actual solar cells, the top surface possesses nonideal surface profiles due to imperfections associated with the metal grid lines and wet etching processes. These imperfections scatter light in excess of that expected by diffraction only, thereby leading to additional absorption. The slight discrepancies between the experimental measurements and FDTD simulations are likely due to such nonidealities of the etched surface relief geometries, also with variations in thickness and refractive index of epi-layers across the wafer. Furthermore, the bending durability of the flexible solar cells with an area of 32.7 mm
2
is successfully demonstrated up to 1000 cycles (50 times per minute) at a radius of curvature of ∼15 mm without any apparent change in device characteristics, as shown in
Figure
3
d.

Figure
4
a–d shows changes in the electrical properties of solar cells with and without the Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer under conditions of 85 °C and 85% relative humidity (RH). As shown in
Figure
4
a,b,
V
oc
and
J
sc
values remain relatively stable in the case of encapsulated and nonencapsulated solar cells. However, in the cases of FF and power conversion efficiency, these values of nonencapsulated solar cells decreased by 12 and 16%, respectively, compared to the initial value, as shown in
Figure
4
c,d. In contrast, solar cells with the Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer are observed to be stable during the test. The degradation of solar cells resulting from moisture is closely related to shunt paths.
(30,36)
We use the Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer as a moisture barrier, which prevents the degradation of solar cells.

div.p:
Figure 4. Evolution of (a)
V
oc
, (b)
J
sc
, (c) FF, and (d) efficiency as a function of time at 85 °C and 85% RH conditions.

div.div:
The specific power is considered a key parameter when assessing the suitability of the PV technology for lightweight applications. The specific power of the flexible dual-junction solar cells is calculated to be >5000 W/kg, assuming a power output of 27.4 mW/cm
2
under the AM 1.5G solar spectrum. This calculation assumes that the density of the polyimide film is 1.42 g/cm
3
and that the density of each layer of the solar cell is the same as that of GaAs (5.32 g/cm
3
). Since the density of the actual layer has a smaller value than that of GaAs, the real specific power of the device is expected to have a larger value. This specific power is the highest reported thus far for flexible III–V PV devices and provides a remarkable opportunity for producing lightweight and high-efficiency PV modules.
Figure
5
shows the benchmark of specific power as a function of solar cell efficiency.
(20,21,24,25,27,28,41,42)
The reason why we can significantly increase the specific power compared to conventional flexible III–V PV devices is that the weight of the PV devices is dramatically reduced by using an extremely lightweight polyimide film (∼13 μm) as a substrate and thin metal layers (∼140 nm) as bonding materials. Further improvement in cell efficiency and cell weight reduction will provide high specific power values of over 10,000 W/kg.

div.p: Figure 5. Benchmark of specific power.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we have fabricated ultra-lightweight, flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer that has the dramatically high specific power of >5000 W/kg using a metal bonding technique. We successfully transferred an InGaP/GaAs dual-junction solar cell to a polyimide film. A lightweight and thin polyimide film (∼13 μm) was used as a substrate, and extremely thin metal layers (∼140 nm) that consisted of Pt and Au were used as the bonding layer. In particular, this bonding layer was integrated into our solar cell structure as the back Ohmic contact to facilitate an additional reduction in PV cost. In addition, we have developed an encapsulation layer consisting of Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
that exhibits an ARC effect through FDTD simulation. The efficiency of the flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer under AM 1.5G illumination at 1000 W/m
2
and room temperature is 27.4%, which is increased by ∼6.3% compared to that when solar cells are not encapsulated. The observed results of the flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
encapsulation layers after 500 h under conditions of 85 °C and 85% RH demonstrate the effectiveness of the Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
layers as a good moisture barrier. Collectively, these approaches enable an increase in possibilities for applying flexible III–V solar cells in mobile equipment or wearable devices.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
InGaP/GaAs solar cell wafers were supplied by Korea Photonics Technology Institute (KOPTI). The polymer film was laminated onto a glass substrate coated with a layer of polydimethylsiloxane (10 μm) as a temporary support. Solar cell wafers were bonded with the polymer film (Kapton, DuPont, ∼13 μm) using a metal bonding technique.
(38)
This process began with the deposition of Pt (10 nm) and Au (60 nm) onto the polymer film and solar cell wafer, respectively, using an electron-beam evaporator. Then, the surfaces of the solar cell wafer and polymer film on Pt and Au were treated by Ar plasma using an RIE chamber for surface activation. Next, the polymer film and solar cell wafer were bonded manually in air with light hand pressure. After metal bonding, the GaAs-based layer and InGaP-based layer were selectively etched to expose the GaAs contact layer using a H
3
PO
4
/H
2
O
2
/deionized water (1:1:5) solution and a H
3
PO
4
/HCl (3:1) solution, respectively. Photolithography with a negative photoresist (AZ 2035, MicroChemicals) defined Pd, Ge, and Au patterns on the GaAs contact layer. Subsequent electron-beam evaporation and liftoff yielded the top contact grid of Pd/Ge/Au (20/40/300 nm). The next step was device isolation. The cell area was defined by gas mesa etching using ICP–RIE. When fabrication of the solar cell was complete, the deposition of Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
on the solar cells was conducted using ALD and PECVD. The final step was that the device was peeled off the glass; thus, flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer were fabricated.

The fabricated PV devices were placed under constant AM 1.5G illumination from an ABET Sun 2000 solar simulator at an intensity of 1000 W/m
2
and room temperature. XRD (ATX-G, Rigaku, Japan) was used to investigate the successful epitaxial transfer and metal bonding. Field emission SEM (Teneo VS) was used to observe the bonding interface between the polymer film and the InGaP/GaAs solar cell wafer. FDTD simulation tools were used to confirm experimental measurements of the ARC effect of Al
2
O
3
and SiO
2
. Flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with and without an Al
2
O
3
/SiO
2
encapsulation layer were exposed to conditions of 85 °C and 85% RH over 500 h using environmental test chambers (TH-TG-180, Jeio Tech Co. Ltd., Korea).

Reb, Lennart K.; Boehmer, Michael; Predeschly, Benjamin; Grott, Sebastian; Weindl, Christian L.; Ivandekic, Goran I.; Guo, Renjun; Dreissigacker, Christoph; Gernhaeuser, Roman; Meyer, Andreas; Mueller-Buschbaum, Peter

Perovskite and org. solar cells possess a revolutionary potential for space applications. The thin-film solar cells can be processed onto thin polymer foils that enable an exceptional specific power, i.e., obtainable elec. power per mass, being superior to their inorg. counterparts. However, research toward space applications was mainly restricted to terrestrial conditions so far. Here, we report the launch of perovskite and org. solar cells of different architectures on a suborbital rocket flight. This is an in situ demonstration of their functionality and power generation under space conditions. We measured solar cell current-voltage characteristics in variable illumination states due to different rocket orientations during flight. Under strong solar irradiance, the solar cells perform efficiently, and they even produce power with weak diffuse light reflected from Earth's surface. These results highlight both the suitability for near-Earth applications as well as the potential for deep-space missions for these innovative technologies.

Wearable electronics represent a significant paradigm shift in consumer electronics since they eliminate the necessity for sep. carriage of devices. In particular, integration of flexible electronic devices with clothes, glasses, watches, and skin will bring new opportunities beyond what can be imagined by current inflexible counterparts. Although considerable progresses have been seen for wearable electronics, lithium rechargeable batteries, the power sources of the devices, do not keep pace with such progresses due to tenuous mech. stabilities, causing them to remain as the limiting elements in the entire technol. Herein, we revisit the key components of the battery (current collector, binder, and separator) and replace them with the materials that support robust mech. endurance of the battery. The final full-cells in the forms of clothes and watchstraps exhibited comparable electrochem. performance to those of conventional metal foil-based cells even under severe folding-unfolding motions simulating actual wearing conditions. Furthermore, the wearable textile battery was integrated with flexible and lightwt. solar cells on the battery pouch to enable convenient solar-charging capabilities.

Wearable electronics fabricated on lightwt. and flexible substrate are believed to have great potential for portable devices, but their applications are limited by the life span of their batteries. We propose a hybridized self-charging power textile system with the aim of simultaneously collecting outdoor sunshine and random body motion energies and then storing them in an energy storage unit. Both of the harvested energies can be easily converted into electricity by using fiber-shaped dye-sensitized solar cells (for solar energy) and fiber-shaped tribo-elec. nanogenerators (for random body motion energy) and then further stored as chem. energy in fiber-shaped supercapacitors. Because of the all-fiber-shaped structure of the entire system, our proposed hybridized self-charging textile system can be easily woven into electronic textiles to fabricate smart clothes to sustainably operate mobile or wearable electronics.

For almost sixty years, solar energy for space applications has relied on inorg. photovoltaics, evolving from solar cells made of single cryst. silicon to triple junctions based on germanium and III-V alloys. The class of org.-based photovoltaics, which ranges from all-org. to hybrid perovskites, has the potential of becoming a disruptive technol. in space applications, thanks to the unique combination of appealing intrinsic properties (e.g. record high specific power, tunable absorption window) and processing possibilities. Here, we report on the launch of the stratospheric mission OSCAR, which demonstrated for the first time org.-based solar cell operation in extra-terrestrial conditions. This successful maiden flight for org.-based photovoltaics opens a new paradigm for solar electricity in space, from satellites to orbital and planetary space stations.

A review. This paper describes the technol. status of and some challenges in the manufg. of Cu(In,Ga)Se2 (CIGS)-based solar cells on flexible polymer and metal substrates. Substrate characteristics such as thermal expansion properties and stability, surface roughness, or substrate compn., strongly influence growth and properties of the following layers. For example, adhesion failure, cracking, or contamination by diffusion of impurities from the substrate may occur with some substrates. Aspects of (external) sodium incorporation into CIGS are discussed for high and low CIGS deposition temp. Low-temp. deposition processes are particularly important when polyimide substrates are used. The elec. insulation of metal foils by dielec. barriers (e.g., silicon oxide or aluminum oxide) allows the fabrication of monolithically integrated modules. A soft and selective patterning technique based on laser scribing and mask-free photolithog. is described. Working modules as large as 20 cm × 30 cm were achieved with these methods.

The paper reviews with 102 refs. recent developments in the field of amorphous-silicon-based thin-film solar cells and discusses potentials for further improvements. Creative efforts in materials research, device physics, and process engineering have led to highly efficient solar cells based on amorphous hydrogenated silicon. Sophisticated multijunction solar cell designs make use of its unique material properties and strongly suppress light induced degrdn. Texture-etching of sputtered ZnO:Al films is presented as a novel technique to design optimized light trapping schemes for silicon thin-film solar cells in both p-i-n and n-i-p device structure. Necessary efforts will be discussed to close the efficiency gap between the highest stabilized efficiencies demonstrated on lab scale and efficiencies achieved in prodn. In case of a-Si:H/a-Si:H stacked cells prepd. on glass substrates, significant redn. of process-related losses and the development of superior TCO substrates on large areas promise distinctly higher module efficiencies. A discussion of future perspectives comprises the potential of new deposition techniques and concepts combining the advantages of amorphous and cryst. silicon thin-film solar cells.

Organo-lead halide perovskite solar cells have gained enormous significance and have now achieved power conversion efficiencies of ∼20%. However, the potential toxicity of lead in these systems raises environmental concerns for widespread deployment. Here we investigate solvent effects on the crystn. of the lead-free methylammonium tin triiodide (CH3NH3SnI3) perovskite films in a soln. growth process. Highly uniform, pinhole-free perovskite films are obtained from a DMSO (DMSO) soln. via a transitional SnI2·3DMSO intermediate phase. This high-quality perovskite film enables the realization of heterojunction depleted solar cells based on mesoporous TiO2 layer but in the absence of any hole-transporting material with an unprecedented photocurrent up to 21 mA cm-2. Charge extn. and transient photovoltage decay measurements reveal high carrier densities in the CH3NH3SnI3 perovskite device which are one order of magnitude larger than CH3NH3PbI3-based devices but with comparable recombination lifetimes in both devices. The relatively high background dark carrier d. of the Sn-based perovskite is responsible for the lower photovoltaic efficiency in comparison to the Pb-based analogs. These results provide important progress toward achieving improved perovskite morphol. control in realizing soln.-processed highly efficient lead-free perovskite solar cells.

Minority carrier lifetime degradation in boron-doped Czochralski silicon
Glunz, S. W.; Rein, S.; Lee, J. Y.; Warta, W.
Journal of Applied Physics
(

.

American Institute of Physics

The minority carrier lifetime in B-doped O-contaminated Czochralski (Cz) Si is strongly reduced under illumination or carrier injection. This process can be fully reversed by a 200° anneal step. In several recent studies it was shown that B and O are the major components of the underlying metastable Cz-specific defect. The energy level of the defect in its active state A was detd. to be around midgap while the energy level of the defect in its passive state P is very shallow. The Cz-specific defect in its passive state can be identified with the shallow thermal donor. The kinetics of the excess carrier-induced transformation from state P to state A can be described using recombination-enhanced defect reaction theory. From these exptl. facts different solns. for the redn. or elimination of the metastable defect are suggested. Two promising solns. are discussed in more detail: the use of Ga-doped Cz Si and the introduction of high-temp. anneals into the process sequence. Ga-doped Cz Si shows no degrdn. and excellent lifetimes over a wide resistivity range, although the concn. of interstitial O is in the same range as in std. Cz Si. Stable solar cell efficiencies comparable to FZ Si were achieved. If std. B-doped Cz Si is used, the defect concn. can be reduced permanently by a high-temp. anneal using conventional tube or rapid thermal processing. This leads to an improvement of the carrier lifetime by a factor of 2-3. Nevertheless, it is always necessary to use an optimized set of process parameters because otherwise the lifetime of all O-contaminated materials (including Ga-doped Cz Si) is severely reduced.

Degrdn. of minority carrier lifetime under illumination occurs in boron-contg. Czochralski silicon of both p- and n-type. In n-Si, the recombination center responsible for degrdn. is identical to the fast-stage center (FRC) known for p-Si, where it is produced at a rate proportional to the squared hole concn., p2. Holes in n-Si are the excess minority carriers-of a relatively low concn.; hence, the time scale of FRC generation is increased by several orders of magnitude when compared to p-Si. The degrdn. kinetics, which is nonlinear, due to dependence of p on the current concn. of FRC, is well reproduced by simulations. The injection level dependence of the lifetime shows that FRC exists in 3 charge states (- 1, 0, + 1) possessing 2 energy levels. Comparison of n-Si samples of various electron concns. shows that FRC emerges by the reconstruction of a latent BsO2 complex of a substitutional boron and an oxygen dimer (while the major recombination center in p-Si denoted SRC was previously found to emerge by reconstruction of BiO2 defect involving an interstitial boron atom). A model of the BsO2 reconfiguration into FRC through an intermediate state accounts for the rate const. dependence on p, which is reduced to a p2 proportionality, under certain conditions. An efficiency of 40.7% was measured and independently confirmed for a metamorphic three-junction GaInP/GaInAs/Ge cell under the std. spectrum for terrestrial concentrator solar cells at 240 suns (24.0 W/cm2, air-mass 1.5D, low aerosol optical depth, 25°). This is the initial demonstration of a solar cell with over 40% efficiency, and is the highest solar conversion efficiency yet achieved for any type of photovoltaic device. Lattice-matched concentrator cells have now reached 40.1% efficiency. Flexible thin film (In)GaAs solar cells are grown by metalorg. chem. vapor deposition on GaAs substrates and transferred to 30 μm thick Au foil by internal stress-assisted epitaxial lift-off processes. The internal stress is induced by replacing the solar cell epi-layers from GaAs to In0.015Ga0.985As, which has a slightly larger lattice const. The compressive strained layer thickness was varied from 0-4.5 μm to investigate the effect of the internal stress on the epitaxial lift-off time. The etching time in the epitaxial lift-off process was reduced from 36-4 h by employing a GaAs/In0.015Ga0.985As heterojunction structure that has a compressive film stress of -59.0 MPa. It was found that the partially strained epi-structure contributed to the much faster lateral etching rate with spontaneous bending. Although an efficiency degrdn. problem occurred in the strained solar cell, it was solved by optimizing the epitaxial growth conditions. (c) 2017 American Institute of Physics.

In this report, we describe a unique roll-to-roll plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition (R2R-PECVD) technique to grow high-quality single-cryst.-like Ge films on flexible metal foils, an important advancement towards scalable processing of epitaxial Ge films at low-cost. Ion-beam assisted deposition was used to create single-cryst.-like substrate templates to enable epitaxial growth of Ge films. The Ge films were highly (004) oriented, biaxially-textured and showed remarkable cryst. quality, equiv. to single-crystal Ge wafers. Subsequently, the Ge films on metal foils were used as substrates to fabricate flexible GaAs single-junction solar cell by metal-oxide chem. vapor deposition (MOCVD). The champion device showed efficiency of 11.5%, and the av. efficiency of four devices was 8% at 1 sun, the highest reported on GaAs PV directly deposited on alternative flexible substrates. Devices made on CVD-Ge film exhibited significantly improved performance compared to the ones grown on sputtered Ge films. Scalable prodn. of inexpensive and flexible epi-Ge films will not only be useful for developing low-cost and high-performance III-V solar cells, but also for emerging flexible electronic devices applications.

There has been much interest in developing a thin-film solar cell because it is lightwt. and flexible. The GaAs thin-film solar cell is a top contender in the thin-film solar cell market in that it has a high power conversion efficiency (PCE) compared to that of other thin-film solar cells. There are two common structures for the GaAs solar cell: n (emitter)-on-p (base) and p-on-n. The former performs better due to its high collection efficiency because the electron diffusion length of the p-type base region is much longer than the hole diffusion length of the n-type base region. However, it has been limited to fabricate highly efficient n-on-p single-junction GaAs thin film solar cell on a flexible substrate due to tech. obstacles. We investigated a simple and fast epitaxial lift-off (ELO) method that uses a stress originating from a Cr/Au bilayer on a 125-μm-thick flexible substrate. A metal combination of AuBe/Pt/Au is employed as a new p-type ohmic contact with which an n-on-p single-junction GaAs thin-film solar cell on flexible substrate was successfully fabricated. The PCE of the fabricated single-junction GaAs thin-film solar cells reached 22.08% under air mass 1.5 global illumination.

We demonstrate ultrathin-film, single-crystal InP Schottky-type solar cells mounted on flexible plastic substrates. The lightly p-doped InP cell is grown epitaxially on an InP substrate by gas source mol. beam epitaxy. The InP substrate is removed via selective chem. wet-etching after the epitaxial layers are cold-welded to a 25 μm thick Kapton sheet, followed by the deposition of an indium tin oxide top contact that forms the Schottky barrier with InP. The power conversion efficiency of the solar cell under 1 sun is 10.2 ± 1.0%, and its sp. power is 2.0 ± 0.2 kW/kg. The ultrathin-film solar cells can tolerate both tensile and compressive stress by bending over a <1 cm radius without damage. (c) 2009 American Institute of Physics.

Compd. semiconductors like GaAs provide advantages over Si for many applications, owing to their direct bandgaps and high electron mobilities. Examples range from efficient photovoltaic devices to r.f. electronics and most forms of optoelectronics. However, growing large, high quality wafers of these materials, and intimately integrating them on Si or amorphous substrates (such as glass or plastic) is expensive, which restricts their use. Here we describe materials and fabrication concepts that address many of these challenges, through the use of films of GaAs or AlGaAs grown in thick, multilayer epitaxial assemblies, then sepd. from each other and distributed on foreign substrates by printing. This method yields large quantities of high quality semiconductor material capable of device integration in large area formats, in a manner that also allows the wafer to be reused for addnl. growths. We demonstrate some capabilities of this approach with 3 different applications: GaAs-based metal semiconductor field effect transistors and logic gates on plates of glass, near-IR imaging devices on wafers of Si, and photovoltaic modules on sheets of plastic. These results illustrate the implementation of compd. semiconductors such as GaAs in applications whose cost structures, formats, area coverages or modes of use are incompatible with conventional growth or integration strategies.

As the demand for flexible, rollable, and foldable displays grows, various state-of-the-art component technologies, including thin-film transistors (TFTs), electrodes, thin-film encapsulations (TFEs), and touch screen panels, have been developed based on org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) with flexible org. layers. Developing highly reliable flexible OLEDs is essential to realize flexible displays, but the flexible encapsulation technol. still has tech. difficulties and issues to be addressed. This review covers the recent developments in encapsulation technologies, particularly their material and structural designs, for highly reliable, flexible OLEDs. The soln. concepts for the existing tech. hurdles in flexible encapsulations are addressed. Among the various advanced flexible encapsulation technologies developed so far, neutral-axis engineering with a thin metal layer and a crack arrester is introduced.

In this work, we employ at. layer deposition (ALD) to form Al2O3 layer as an encapsulant for perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Al2O3 layer deposited at temp. as low as 95°C achieves water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of 1.84 × 10-2 g m-2 d-1 at 45°C-100%RH when thermal ALD is used. In order to test the moisture barrier capability of Al2O3 layer for PSCs, mesoporous perovskite devices, with spiro-OMeTAD or PTAA as hole transport layer (HTM) encapsulated by 50 nm Al2O3 film, are exposed to 65°C-85%RH for 350 h and their stabilities are monitored. We find that the color of perovskite does not change after 350 h of exposure regardless of the type of HTM used. With regards to Th-ALD encapsulated devices, PTAA based PSCs experienced a smaller power conversion efficiency (PCE) drop than spiro-OMeTAD based PSCs after thermal stress at 65°C. This is due to the presence of pinholes within spiro-OMeTAD layer after thermal stress which are not obsd. in PTAA. Finally, we successfully achieve excellent durability test results for mesoporous (HC(NH2)2PbI3)0.85(CH3NH3PbBr3)0.15/PTAA devices encapsulated by 50 nm Al2O3 with less than 4% drop in PCE after 7500 h (> 10 mo) of exposure to 50%RH under room temp.

Stability enhancement of GaInP/GaAs/Ge triple-junction solar cells using Al2O3 moisture-barrier layer
Kim, Ju-Hee; Choi, Eun Young; Kim, Bu-Jong; Han, Ekyu; Park, Nochang

A method to enhance the operational stability of GaInP/GaAs/Ge triple-junction (III-V) solar cells is proposed. To accomplish this, plasma-enhanced at. layer deposition (PEALD) was employed, thereby forming a thin Al2O3 film as a moisture barrier layer. As obsd., creation of a 50 nm Al2O3 layer demonstrated a water-vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of nearly 1.71 × 10-2 g/m2-day at 45°C and 100% RH. Subsequent to Al2O3 deposition, solar cells were laminated with ethylene-vinyl acetate (EVA) and ethylene chloro-trifluoroethylene (ECTFE) films and exposed to conditions of 85°C and 85% RH for 1000 h. As obsd., when encapsulated within the 50 nm thin Al2O3 film, the III-V solar cells demonstrated greater stability over the said 1000 h period. On the other hand, III-V solar cells not encapsulated within the said Al2O3 films demonstrated an approx. 25% redn. in max. power. Anal. results reveal that the obsd. degrdn. in III-V solar cell performance under high humidity conditions can be attributed to the oxidn. of GaAs, which causes damage of the middle junction, and hence, drop in shunt resistance (RSH). Overall, III-V solar cells encapsulated within 50 nm Al2O3 demonstrated less than 1% drop in the power-conversion efficiency after 1000 h.

Ultra-high-throughput Production of III-V/Si Wafer for Electronic and Photonic Applications
Geum, Dae-Myeong; Park, Min-Su; Lim, Ju Young; Yang, Hyun-Duk; Song, Jin Dong; Kim, Chang Zoo; Yoon, Euijoon; Kim, SangHyeon; Choi, Won Jun

Si-based integrated circuits have been intensively developed over the past several decades through ultimate device scaling. However, the Si technol. has reached the phys. limitations of the scaling. These limitations have fuelled the search for alternative active materials (for transistors) and the introduction of optical interconnects (called "Si photonics"). A series of attempts to circumvent the Si technol. limits are based on the use of III-V compd. semiconductor due to their superior benefits, such as high electron mobility and direct bandgap. To use their phys. properties on a Si platform, the formation of high-quality III-V films on the Si (III-V/Si) is the basic technol. ; however, implementing this technol. using a high-throughput process is not easy. Here, we report new concepts for an ultra-high-throughput heterogeneous integration of high-quality III-V films on the Si using the wafer bonding and epitaxial lift off (ELO) technique. We describe the ultra-fast ELO and also the re-use of the III-V donor wafer after III-V/Si formation. These approaches provide an ultra-high-throughput fabrication of III-V/Si substrates with a high-quality film, which leads to a dramatic cost redn. As proof-of-concept devices, this paper demonstrates GaAs-based high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs), solar cells, and hetero-junction phototransistors on Si substrates.

Wearable flexible electronics often require sustainable power sources that are also mech. flexible to survive the extreme bending that accompanies their general use. In general, thinner microelectronic devices are under less strain when bent. This paper describes strategies to realize ultra-thin GaAs photovoltaics through the interlayer adhesiveless transfer-printing of vertical-type devices onto metal surfaces. The vertical-type GaAs photovoltaic devices recycle reflected photons by means of bottom electrodes. Systematic studies with four different types of solar microcells indicate that the vertical-type solar microcells, at only a quarter of the thickness of similarly designed lateral-type cells, generate a level of elec. power similar to that of thicker cells. The exptl. results along with the theor. anal. conducted here show that the ultra-thin vertical-type solar microcells are durable under extreme bending and thus suitable for use in the manufg. of wearable flexible electronics. Structural dependences of localization and recombination of photogenerated carriers in the top GaInP subcells of GaInP/GaAs double-junction tandem solar cells
Deng, Zhuo; Ning, Jiqiang; Su, Zhicheng; Xu, Shijie; Xing, Zheng; Wang, Rongxin; Lu, Shulong; Dong, Jianrong; Zhang, Baoshun; Yang, Hui
ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

In high-efficiency GaInP/GaAs double-junction tandem solar cells, GaInP layers play a central role in detg. the performance of the solar cells. Therefore, gaining a deeper understanding of the optoelectronic processes in GaInP layers is crucial for improving the energy conversion efficiency of GaInP-based photovoltaic devices. In this work, we firmly show strong dependences of localization and recombination of photogenerated carriers in the top GaInP subcells in the GaInP/GaAs double-junction tandem solar cells on the substrate misorientation angle with excitation intensity- and temp.-dependent photoluminescence (PL). The entire solar cell structures including GaInP layers were grown with metalorg. chem. vapor deposition on GaAs substrates with misorientation angles of 2° (denoted as Sample 2°) and 7° (Sample 7°) off (100) toward (111)B. The PL spectral features of the two top GaInP subcells, as well as their excitation-power and temp. dependences exhibit remarkable variation on the misorientation angle. In Sample 2°, the dominant localization mechanism and luminescence channels are due to the energy potential min. caused by highly ordered at. domains; In Sample 7°, the main localization and radiative recombination of photogenerated carriers occur in the atomically disordered regions. Our results reveal a more precise picture on the localization and recombination mechanisms of photogenerated carriers in the top GaInP subcells, which could be the crucial factors in controlling the optoelectronic efficiency of the GaInP-based multijunction photovoltaic devices.

Characteristics of InGaP/GaAs double junction thin film solar cells on a flexible metallic substrate
Zhao, Bin; Tang, Xian-Sheng; Huo, Wen-Xue; Jiang, Yang; Ma, Zi-Guang; Wang, Lu; Wang, Wen-Xin; Chen, Hong; Jia, Hai-Qiang
Solar Energy

We have investigated the characteristics of InGaP/GaAs double junction thin film solar cells (TFSCs) on a flexible metallic substrate prepd. by electroplating copper (Cu). Both photoluminescence peaks of InGaP and GaAs sub-cells maintained the original positions after transferring the epilayers onto Cu carrier, but a peak shift occurred when the epilayers were bent under intense strain. A slight efficiency improvement up to 29.09% was obtained, compared with 28.25% of conventional structure with GaAs grown substrate under air mass 1.5 (AM1.5) illumination. The TFSCs have a total thickness of about 30μm, showing an excellent flexibility. Performance measurements of TFSCs were conducted under different strain by bent into the corresponding central angles. It was found that the efficiency was keeping more than 90% when the strain was less than 0.1%, although a rapid decrease down to below 45% occurred till the strain was increased to 0.2%. The favorable performance maintaining after up to 100 bending recycles proved the superior mech. stability of the TFSCs. Our presented transferring substrate technol. based on electroplating in this paper enables the TFSCs with an outstanding performance uniformity, a high yield and a large power wt. ratio, which will exhibit an enormous potential to fabricate flexible, low-wt., thin film optoelectronic devices.

A new ultralight flexible amorphous Si (a-Si) solar cell was fabricated on a transparent plastic film substrate. The flexible a-Si solar cell submodule has a power-to-wt. ratio of 275 mW/g. The flexible module is 0.12 mm thick and can be bent to a radius of 5 mm. As the first application of the flexible a-Si solar cell, a solar-powered airplane was developed. The airplane recently succeeded in a trans-continental flight across the US setting new records for solar-powered aviation.

Perovskite and Organic Solar Cells on a Rocket Flight
Reb, Lennart K.; Boehmer, Michael; Predeschly, Benjamin; Grott, Sebastian; Weindl, Christian L.; Ivandekic, Goran I.; Guo, Renjun; Dreissigacker, Christoph; Gernhaeuser, Roman; Meyer, Andreas; Mueller-Buschbaum, Peter

Perovskite and org. solar cells possess a revolutionary potential for space applications. The thin-film solar cells can be processed onto thin polymer foils that enable an exceptional specific power, i.e., obtainable elec. power per mass, being superior to their inorg. counterparts. However, research toward space applications was mainly restricted to terrestrial conditions so far. Here, we report the launch of perovskite and org. solar cells of different architectures on a suborbital rocket flight. This is an in situ demonstration of their functionality and power generation under space conditions. We measured solar cell current-voltage characteristics in variable illumination states due to different rocket orientations during flight. Under strong solar irradiance, the solar cells perform efficiently, and they even produce power with weak diffuse light reflected from Earth's surface. These results highlight both the suitability for near-Earth applications as well as the potential for deep-space missions for these innovative technologies.

Wearable electronics represent a significant paradigm shift in consumer electronics since they eliminate the necessity for sep. carriage of devices. In particular, integration of flexible electronic devices with clothes, glasses, watches, and skin will bring new opportunities beyond what can be imagined by current inflexible counterparts. Although considerable progresses have been seen for wearable electronics, lithium rechargeable batteries, the power sources of the devices, do not keep pace with such progresses due to tenuous mech. stabilities, causing them to remain as the limiting elements in the entire technol. Herein, we revisit the key components of the battery (current collector, binder, and separator) and replace them with the materials that support robust mech. endurance of the battery. The final full-cells in the forms of clothes and watchstraps exhibited comparable electrochem. performance to those of conventional metal foil-based cells even under severe folding-unfolding motions simulating actual wearing conditions. Furthermore, the wearable textile battery was integrated with flexible and lightwt. solar cells on the battery pouch to enable convenient solar-charging capabilities.

Wearable electronics fabricated on lightwt. and flexible substrate are believed to have great potential for portable devices, but their applications are limited by the life span of their batteries. We propose a hybridized self-charging power textile system with the aim of simultaneously collecting outdoor sunshine and random body motion energies and then storing them in an energy storage unit. Both of the harvested energies can be easily converted into electricity by using fiber-shaped dye-sensitized solar cells (for solar energy) and fiber-shaped tribo-elec. nanogenerators (for random body motion energy) and then further stored as chem. energy in fiber-shaped supercapacitors. Because of the all-fiber-shaped structure of the entire system, our proposed hybridized self-charging textile system can be easily woven into electronic textiles to fabricate smart clothes to sustainably operate mobile or wearable electronics.

For almost sixty years, solar energy for space applications has relied on inorg. photovoltaics, evolving from solar cells made of single cryst. silicon to triple junctions based on germanium and III-V alloys. The class of org.-based photovoltaics, which ranges from all-org. to hybrid perovskites, has the potential of becoming a disruptive technol. in space applications, thanks to the unique combination of appealing intrinsic properties (e.g. record high specific power, tunable absorption window) and processing possibilities. Here, we report on the launch of the stratospheric mission OSCAR, which demonstrated for the first time org.-based solar cell operation in extra-terrestrial conditions. This successful maiden flight for org.-based photovoltaics opens a new paradigm for solar electricity in space, from satellites to orbital and planetary space stations.

A review. This paper describes the technol. status of and some challenges in the manufg. of Cu(In,Ga)Se2 (CIGS)-based solar cells on flexible polymer and metal substrates. Substrate characteristics such as thermal expansion properties and stability, surface roughness, or substrate compn., strongly influence growth and properties of the following layers. For example, adhesion failure, cracking, or contamination by diffusion of impurities from the substrate may occur with some substrates. Aspects of (external) sodium incorporation into CIGS are discussed for high and low CIGS deposition temp. Low-temp. deposition processes are particularly important when polyimide substrates are used. The elec. insulation of metal foils by dielec. barriers (e.g., silicon oxide or aluminum oxide) allows the fabrication of monolithically integrated modules. A soft and selective patterning technique based on laser scribing and mask-free photolithog. is described. Working modules as large as 20 cm × 30 cm were achieved with these methods.

The paper reviews with 102 refs. recent developments in the field of amorphous-silicon-based thin-film solar cells and discusses potentials for further improvements. Creative efforts in materials research, device physics, and process engineering have led to highly efficient solar cells based on amorphous hydrogenated silicon. Sophisticated multijunction solar cell designs make use of its unique material properties and strongly suppress light induced degrdn. Texture-etching of sputtered ZnO:Al films is presented as a novel technique to design optimized light trapping schemes for silicon thin-film solar cells in both p-i-n and n-i-p device structure. Necessary efforts will be discussed to close the efficiency gap between the highest stabilized efficiencies demonstrated on lab scale and efficiencies achieved in prodn. In case of a-Si:H/a-Si:H stacked cells prepd. on glass substrates, significant redn. of process-related losses and the development of superior TCO substrates on large areas promise distinctly higher module efficiencies. A discussion of future perspectives comprises the potential of new deposition techniques and concepts combining the advantages of amorphous and cryst. silicon thin-film solar cells.

We show that the power conversion efficiency of org. photovoltaic devices based on a conjugated polymer/methanofullerene blend is dramatically affected by mol. morphol. By structuring the blend to be a more intimate mixt. that contains less phase segregation of methanofullerenes, and simultaneously increasing the degree of interactions between conjugated polymer chains, we have fabricated a device with a power conversion efficiency of 2.5% under AM1.5 illumination. This is a nearly threefold enhancement over previously reported values for such a device, and it approaches what is needed for the practical use of these devices for harvesting energy from sunlight.

Organo-lead halide perovskite solar cells have gained enormous significance and have now achieved power conversion efficiencies of ∼20%. However, the potential toxicity of lead in these systems raises environmental concerns for widespread deployment. Here we investigate solvent effects on the crystn. of the lead-free methylammonium tin triiodide (CH3NH3SnI3) perovskite films in a soln. growth process. Highly uniform, pinhole-free perovskite films are obtained from a DMSO (DMSO) soln. via a transitional SnI2·3DMSO intermediate phase. This high-quality perovskite film enables the realization of heterojunction depleted solar cells based on mesoporous TiO2 layer but in the absence of any hole-transporting material with an unprecedented photocurrent up to 21 mA cm-2. Charge extn. and transient photovoltage decay measurements reveal high carrier densities in the CH3NH3SnI3 perovskite device which are one order of magnitude larger than CH3NH3PbI3-based devices but with comparable recombination lifetimes in both devices. The relatively high background dark carrier d. of the Sn-based perovskite is responsible for the lower photovoltaic efficiency in comparison to the Pb-based analogs. These results provide important progress toward achieving improved perovskite morphol. control in realizing soln.-processed highly efficient lead-free perovskite solar cells.

Minority carrier lifetime degradation in boron-doped Czochralski silicon
Glunz, S. W.; Rein, S.; Lee, J. Y.; Warta, W.

The minority carrier lifetime in B-doped O-contaminated Czochralski (Cz) Si is strongly reduced under illumination or carrier injection. This process can be fully reversed by a 200° anneal step. In several recent studies it was shown that B and O are the major components of the underlying metastable Cz-specific defect. The energy level of the defect in its active state A was detd. to be around midgap while the energy level of the defect in its passive state P is very shallow. The Cz-specific defect in its passive state can be identified with the shallow thermal donor. The kinetics of the excess carrier-induced transformation from state P to state A can be described using recombination-enhanced defect reaction theory. From these exptl. facts different solns. for the redn. or elimination of the metastable defect are suggested. Two promising solns. are discussed in more detail: the use of Ga-doped Cz Si and the introduction of high-temp. anneals into the process sequence. Ga-doped Cz Si shows no degrdn. and excellent lifetimes over a wide resistivity range, although the concn. of interstitial O is in the same range as in std. Cz Si. Stable solar cell efficiencies comparable to FZ Si were achieved. If std. B-doped Cz Si is used, the defect concn. can be reduced permanently by a high-temp. anneal using conventional tube or rapid thermal processing. This leads to an improvement of the carrier lifetime by a factor of 2-3. Nevertheless, it is always necessary to use an optimized set of process parameters because otherwise the lifetime of all O-contaminated materials (including Ga-doped Cz Si) is severely reduced.

Degrdn. of minority carrier lifetime under illumination occurs in boron-contg. Czochralski silicon of both p- and n-type. In n-Si, the recombination center responsible for degrdn. is identical to the fast-stage center (FRC) known for p-Si, where it is produced at a rate proportional to the squared hole concn., p2. Holes in n-Si are the excess minority carriers-of a relatively low concn.; hence, the time scale of FRC generation is increased by several orders of magnitude when compared to p-Si. The degrdn. kinetics, which is nonlinear, due to dependence of p on the current concn. of FRC, is well reproduced by simulations. The injection level dependence of the lifetime shows that FRC exists in 3 charge states (- 1, 0, + 1) possessing 2 energy levels. Comparison of n-Si samples of various electron concns. shows that FRC emerges by the reconstruction of a latent BsO2 complex of a substitutional boron and an oxygen dimer (while the major recombination center in p-Si denoted SRC was previously found to emerge by reconstruction of BiO2 defect involving an interstitial boron atom). A model of the BsO2 reconfiguration into FRC through an intermediate state accounts for the rate const. dependence on p, which is reduced to a p2 proportionality, under certain conditions. (c) 2011 American Institute of Physics.

The epitaxial lift-off technique can be used to sep. a III-V solar cell structure from its underlying GaAs substrate. Processing a thin-film cell is somewhat different from a regular cell on substrate. In this work a no. of crit. issues, e.g., a low-temp. anneal front contact and the metal mirror on backside of the thin-film are optimized. Together with an improved active layer material quality, grid mask and anti-reflection coating this leads to thin-film cells as good as cells on a substrate, with record efficiencies for single junction GaAs solar cells of 26.1% for both cell types.

The authors demonstrate a thin, Ge-free III-V semiconductor triple-junction solar cell device structure that achieved 33.8%, 30.6%, and 38.9% efficiencies under the std. 1 sun global spectrum, space spectrum, and concd. direct spectrum at 81 suns, resp. The device consists of 1.8 eV Ga0.5In0.5P, 1.4 eV GaAs, and 1.0 eV In0.3Ga0.7As p-n junctions grown monolithically in an inverted configuration on GaAs substrates by organometallic vapor phase epitaxy. The lattice-mismatched In0.3Ga0.7As junction was grown last on a graded GaxIn1-xP buffer. The substrate was removed after the structure was mounted to a structural handle. The current-matched, series-connected junctions produced a total open-circuit voltage >2.95 V at 1 sun.

An efficiency of 40.7% was measured and independently confirmed for a metamorphic three-junction GaInP/GaInAs/Ge cell under the std. spectrum for terrestrial concentrator solar cells at 240 suns (24.0 W/cm2, air-mass 1.5D, low aerosol optical depth, 25°). This is the initial demonstration of a solar cell with over 40% efficiency, and is the highest solar conversion efficiency yet achieved for any type of photovoltaic device. Lattice-matched concentrator cells have now reached 40.1% efficiency. Electron-hole recombination mechanisms are analyzed in metamorphic GaxIn1-xAs and GaxIn1-xP materials, and fundamental power losses are quantified to identify paths to still higher efficiencies.

Conditions were discovered for the selective lift-off of large-area epitaxial AlxGa1-xAs films from the substrate wafers on which they were grown. This process relies upon the creation of a favorable geometry for the outdiffusion of dissolved H2 gas from the etching zone.

We present the heterogeneous integration of GaAs a single-junction solar cell (SC) on copper (Cu) via electroplating and epitaxial lift-off. We characterized the layer quality and the residual strain of the transferred SC layer through X-ray diffraction measurements and Raman spectroscopy. These results indicated that the fabrication process of SCs was quite stable, providing a high-quality film with a relatively small residual compressive strain. In addn., we obtained a peak energy conversion efficiency of 20.8% at 2.5 suns in a solar concentrator.

Flexible thin film (In)GaAs solar cells are grown by metalorg. chem. vapor deposition on GaAs substrates and transferred to 30 μm thick Au foil by internal stress-assisted epitaxial lift-off processes. The internal stress is induced by replacing the solar cell epi-layers from GaAs to In0.015Ga0.985As, which has a slightly larger lattice const. The compressive strained layer thickness was varied from 0-4.5 μm to investigate the effect of the internal stress on the epitaxial lift-off time. The etching time in the epitaxial lift-off process was reduced from 36-4 h by employing a GaAs/In0.015Ga0.985As heterojunction structure that has a compressive film stress of -59.0 MPa. It was found that the partially strained epi-structure contributed to the much faster lateral etching rate with spontaneous bending. Although an efficiency degrdn. problem occurred in the strained solar cell, it was solved by optimizing the epitaxial growth conditions. (c) 2017 American Institute of Physics.

In this report, we describe a unique roll-to-roll plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition (R2R-PECVD) technique to grow high-quality single-cryst.-like Ge films on flexible metal foils, an important advancement towards scalable processing of epitaxial Ge films at low-cost. Ion-beam assisted deposition was used to create single-cryst.-like substrate templates to enable epitaxial growth of Ge films. The Ge films were highly (004) oriented, biaxially-textured and showed remarkable cryst. quality, equiv. to single-crystal Ge wafers. Subsequently, the Ge films on metal foils were used as substrates to fabricate flexible GaAs single-junction solar cell by metal-oxide chem. vapor deposition (MOCVD). The champion device showed efficiency of 11.5%, and the av. efficiency of four devices was 8% at 1 sun, the highest reported on GaAs PV directly deposited on alternative flexible substrates. Devices made on CVD-Ge film exhibited significantly improved performance compared to the ones grown on sputtered Ge films. Scalable prodn. of inexpensive and flexible epi-Ge films will not only be useful for developing low-cost and high-performance III-V solar cells, but also for emerging flexible electronic devices applications.

Highly efficient single-junction GaAs thin-film solar cell on flexible substrate
Moon, Sunghyun; Kim, Kangho; Kim, Youngjo; Heo, Junseok; Lee, Jaejin

There has been much interest in developing a thin-film solar cell because it is lightwt. and flexible. The GaAs thin-film solar cell is a top contender in the thin-film solar cell market in that it has a high power conversion efficiency (PCE) compared to that of other thin-film solar cells. There are two common structures for the GaAs solar cell: n (emitter)-on-p (base) and p-on-n. The former performs better due to its high collection efficiency because the electron diffusion length of the p-type base region is much longer than the hole diffusion length of the n-type base region. However, it has been limited to fabricate highly efficient n-on-p single-junction GaAs thin film solar cell on a flexible substrate due to tech. obstacles. We investigated a simple and fast epitaxial lift-off (ELO) method that uses a stress originating from a Cr/Au bilayer on a 125-μm-thick flexible substrate. A metal combination of AuBe/Pt/Au is employed as a new p-type ohmic contact with which an n-on-p single-junction GaAs thin-film solar cell on flexible substrate was successfully fabricated. The PCE of the fabricated single-junction GaAs thin-film solar cells reached 22.08% under air mass 1.5 global illumination.

We demonstrate ultrathin-film, single-crystal InP Schottky-type solar cells mounted on flexible plastic substrates. The lightly p-doped InP cell is grown epitaxially on an InP substrate by gas source mol. beam epitaxy. The InP substrate is removed via selective chem. wet-etching after the epitaxial layers are cold-welded to a 25 μm thick Kapton sheet, followed by the deposition of an indium tin oxide top contact that forms the Schottky barrier with InP. The power conversion efficiency of the solar cell under 1 sun is 10.2 ± 1.0%, and its sp. power is 2.0 ± 0.2 kW/kg. The ultrathin-film solar cells can tolerate both tensile and compressive stress by bending over a <1 cm radius without damage. (c) 2009 American Institute of Physics.

Compd. semiconductors like GaAs provide advantages over Si for many applications, owing to their direct bandgaps and high electron mobilities. Examples range from efficient photovoltaic devices to r.f. electronics and most forms of optoelectronics. However, growing large, high quality wafers of these materials, and intimately integrating them on Si or amorphous substrates (such as glass or plastic) is expensive, which restricts their use. Here we describe materials and fabrication concepts that address many of these challenges, through the use of films of GaAs or AlGaAs grown in thick, multilayer epitaxial assemblies, then sepd. from each other and distributed on foreign substrates by printing. This method yields large quantities of high quality semiconductor material capable of device integration in large area formats, in a manner that also allows the wafer to be reused for addnl. growths. We demonstrate some capabilities of this approach with 3 different applications: GaAs-based metal semiconductor field effect transistors and logic gates on plates of glass, near-IR imaging devices on wafers of Si, and photovoltaic modules on sheets of plastic. These results illustrate the implementation of compd. semiconductors such as GaAs in applications whose cost structures, formats, area coverages or modes of use are incompatible with conventional growth or integration strategies.

As the demand for flexible, rollable, and foldable displays grows, various state-of-the-art component technologies, including thin-film transistors (TFTs), electrodes, thin-film encapsulations (TFEs), and touch screen panels, have been developed based on org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) with flexible org. layers. Developing highly reliable flexible OLEDs is essential to realize flexible displays, but the flexible encapsulation technol. still has tech. difficulties and issues to be addressed. This review covers the recent developments in encapsulation technologies, particularly their material and structural designs, for highly reliable, flexible OLEDs. The soln. concepts for the existing tech. hurdles in flexible encapsulations are addressed. Among the various advanced flexible encapsulation technologies developed so far, neutral-axis engineering with a thin metal layer and a crack arrester is introduced.

In this work, we employ at. layer deposition (ALD) to form Al2O3 layer as an encapsulant for perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Al2O3 layer deposited at temp. as low as 95°C achieves water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of 1.84 × 10-2 g m-2 d-1 at 45°C-100%RH when thermal ALD is used. In order to test the moisture barrier capability of Al2O3 layer for PSCs, mesoporous perovskite devices, with spiro-OMeTAD or PTAA as hole transport layer (HTM) encapsulated by 50 nm Al2O3 film, are exposed to 65°C-85%RH for 350 h and their stabilities are monitored. We find that the color of perovskite does not change after 350 h of exposure regardless of the type of HTM used. With regards to Th-ALD encapsulated devices, PTAA based PSCs experienced a smaller power conversion efficiency (PCE) drop than spiro-OMeTAD based PSCs after thermal stress at 65°C. This is due to the presence of pinholes within spiro-OMeTAD layer after thermal stress which are not obsd. in PTAA. Finally, we successfully achieve excellent durability test results for mesoporous (HC(NH2)2PbI3)0.85(CH3NH3PbBr3)0.15/PTAA devices encapsulated by 50 nm Al2O3 with less than 4% drop in PCE after 7500 h (> 10 mo) of exposure to 50%RH under room temp.

A method to enhance the operational stability of GaInP/GaAs/Ge triple-junction (III-V) solar cells is proposed. To accomplish this, plasma-enhanced at. layer deposition (PEALD) was employed, thereby forming a thin Al2O3 film as a moisture barrier layer. As obsd., creation of a 50 nm Al2O3 layer demonstrated a water-vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of nearly 1.71 × 10-2 g/m2-day at 45°C and 100% RH. Subsequent to Al2O3 deposition, solar cells were laminated with ethylene-vinyl acetate (EVA) and ethylene chloro-trifluoroethylene (ECTFE) films and exposed to conditions of 85°C and 85% RH for 1000 h. As obsd., when encapsulated within the 50 nm thin Al2O3 film, the III-V solar cells demonstrated greater stability over the said 1000 h period. On the other hand, III-V solar cells not encapsulated within the said Al2O3 films demonstrated an approx. 25% redn. in max. power. Anal. results reveal that the obsd. degrdn. in III-V solar cell performance under high humidity conditions can be attributed to the oxidn. of GaAs, which causes damage of the middle junction, and hence, drop in shunt resistance (RSH). Overall, III-V solar cells encapsulated within 50 nm Al2O3 demonstrated less than 1% drop in the power-conversion efficiency after 1000 h.

Si-based integrated circuits have been intensively developed over the past several decades through ultimate device scaling. However, the Si technol. has reached the phys. limitations of the scaling. These limitations have fuelled the search for alternative active materials (for transistors) and the introduction of optical interconnects (called "Si photonics"). A series of attempts to circumvent the Si technol. limits are based on the use of III-V compd. semiconductor due to their superior benefits, such as high electron mobility and direct bandgap. To use their phys. properties on a Si platform, the formation of high-quality III-V films on the Si (III-V/Si) is the basic technol. ; however, implementing this technol. using a high-throughput process is not easy. Here, we report new concepts for an ultra-high-throughput heterogeneous integration of high-quality III-V films on the Si using the wafer bonding and epitaxial lift off (ELO) technique. We describe the ultra-fast ELO and also the re-use of the III-V donor wafer after III-V/Si formation. These approaches provide an ultra-high-throughput fabrication of III-V/Si substrates with a high-quality film, which leads to a dramatic cost redn. As proof-of-concept devices, this paper demonstrates GaAs-based high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs), solar cells, and hetero-junction phototransistors on Si substrates.

Wearable flexible electronics often require sustainable power sources that are also mech. flexible to survive the extreme bending that accompanies their general use. In general, thinner microelectronic devices are under less strain when bent. This paper describes strategies to realize ultra-thin GaAs photovoltaics through the interlayer adhesiveless transfer-printing of vertical-type devices onto metal surfaces. The vertical-type GaAs photovoltaic devices recycle reflected photons by means of bottom electrodes. Systematic studies with four different types of solar microcells indicate that the vertical-type solar microcells, at only a quarter of the thickness of similarly designed lateral-type cells, generate a level of elec. power similar to that of thicker cells. The exptl. results along with the theor. anal. conducted here show that the ultra-thin vertical-type solar microcells are durable under extreme bending and thus suitable for use in the manufg. of wearable flexible electronics. In high-efficiency GaInP/GaAs double-junction tandem solar cells, GaInP layers play a central role in detg. the performance of the solar cells. Therefore, gaining a deeper understanding of the optoelectronic processes in GaInP layers is crucial for improving the energy conversion efficiency of GaInP-based photovoltaic devices. In this work, we firmly show strong dependences of localization and recombination of photogenerated carriers in the top GaInP subcells in the GaInP/GaAs double-junction tandem solar cells on the substrate misorientation angle with excitation intensity- and temp.-dependent photoluminescence (PL). The entire solar cell structures including GaInP layers were grown with metalorg. chem. vapor deposition on GaAs substrates with misorientation angles of 2° (denoted as Sample 2°) and 7° (Sample 7°) off (100) toward (111)B. The PL spectral features of the two top GaInP subcells, as well as their excitation-power and temp. dependences exhibit remarkable variation on the misorientation angle. In Sample 2°, the dominant localization mechanism and luminescence channels are due to the energy potential min. caused by highly ordered at. domains; In Sample 7°, the main localization and radiative recombination of photogenerated carriers occur in the atomically disordered regions. Our results reveal a more precise picture on the localization and recombination mechanisms of photogenerated carriers in the top GaInP subcells, which could be the crucial factors in controlling the optoelectronic efficiency of the GaInP-based multijunction photovoltaic devices.

We have investigated the characteristics of InGaP/GaAs double junction thin film solar cells (TFSCs) on a flexible metallic substrate prepd. by electroplating copper (Cu). Both photoluminescence peaks of InGaP and GaAs sub-cells maintained the original positions after transferring the epilayers onto Cu carrier, but a peak shift occurred when the epilayers were bent under intense strain. A slight efficiency improvement up to 29.09% was obtained, compared with 28.25% of conventional structure with GaAs grown substrate under air mass 1.5 (AM1.5) illumination. The TFSCs have a total thickness of about 30μm, showing an excellent flexibility. Performance measurements of TFSCs were conducted under different strain by bent into the corresponding central angles. It was found that the efficiency was keeping more than 90% when the strain was less than 0.1%, although a rapid decrease down to below 45% occurred till the strain was increased to 0.2%. The favorable performance maintaining after up to 100 bending recycles proved the superior mech. stability of the TFSCs. Our presented transferring substrate technol. based on electroplating in this paper enables the TFSCs with an outstanding performance uniformity, a high yield and a large power wt. ratio, which will exhibit an enormous potential to fabricate flexible, low-wt., thin film optoelectronic devices.
